Review Surface/interface engineering of high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for energy-related electrochemical reactions Hui Zhao a Zhong-Yong Yuan b ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng 252000, Shandong, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Liaocheng University Liaocheng 252000 Shandong China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng 252000, Shandong, China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 3000350, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education) School of Materials Science and Engineering Nankai University Tianjin 3000350 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 3000350, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review gives the insights into the various strategies of surface/interface engineering of high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for energy-related electrochemical reactions. To date, much efforts have been devoted to the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for hydrogen- and oxygen-involving energy conversion reactions, due to their abundance, low cost and multifunctionally. Surface/interface engineering is found to be effective in achieving novel physicochemical properties and synergistic effects in nanomaterials for electrocatalysis. Among various engineering strategies, heteroatom-doping has been regarded as a most promising method to improve the electrocatalytic performance via the regulation of electronic structure of catalysts, and numerous works were reported on the synthesis method and mechanism investigation of heteroatom-doping electrocatalysts, though the heteroatom-doping can only provide limited active sites. Engineering of other defects such as vacancies and edge sites and construction of heterostructure have shown to open up a potential avenue for the development of noble metal-free electrocatalysts. In addition, surface functionalization can attach various molecules onto the surface of materials to easily modify their physical or chemical properties, being as a promising complement or substitute for offering materials with catalytic properties. This paper gives the insights into the diverse strategies of surface/interface engineering of the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for energy-related electrochemical reactions. The significant advances are summarized. The unique advantages and mechanisms for specific applications are highlighted. The current challenges and outlook of this growing field are also discussed. Keywords Noble metal-free electrocatalysts Electrocatalysis Surface/interface engineering Metal-air battery Overall water splitting 1 Introduction With the aggravation of environmental pollution and the gradually exhausted non-renewable energy resources, the exploration of renewable and clean energy conversion and storage devices has been a common goal for human. For example, rechargeable metal-air batteries, fuel cells, water electrolysis have attracted immense interest in recent years to meet the increasing demand for next-generation energy devices [1–4]. Specifically, rechargeable metal-air batteries and fuel cells hold enormous potential as a platform for electric vehicles and stationary power grid applications due to their low product gas emissions and high efficiency. Water electrolysis that produces hydrogen from water provides a promising route to substitute the conventional used fossil fuels. However, their practical applications are still constrained by several hydrogen- and oxygen- involving reactions, that is, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurred at the cathode of fuel cells, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and ORR occurred at the cathode of metal-air batteries, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and OER occurred at the cathode and anode of water electrolysis, respectively. The main problem originates from the high cost of noble metal catalysts used for them or the inferior efficiency of novel non-noble metal catalysts considered for them [4–7]. Thus, the development of noble metal-free and highly efficient materials that can effectively catalyze the ORR, OER and HER, is pivotal to scale up the technologies. As is known, an excellent electrocatalyst should possess a plenty of exposure of catalytic active sites, high electronic conductivity and superior stability. It is revealed that surface/interface engineering is capable of modulating the catalysts to achieve novel physical and chemical properties and superior synergistic effects, showing significant influences on the electrocatalytic performance due to the increased density of active sites, the optimized electrical conductivity and stability [8–13]. The introduction of defects and construction of heterostructure have played important roles in structural-induced and electronic effect [9,14–18]. The defects can induce charge redistribution, improve conductivity and optimize adsorption energy of materials, thus affecting the electrocatalytic activity [19–22]. The heterostructure materials have demonstrated great electrochemical performance due to the synergistic effect on the interfaces among the multiple components [23]. The presence of interfaces can result in the optimization of electronic configuration through the interfacial electron transfer in the heterostructures. In addition, the surface functionalization is pivotal for the gas-involving catalytic processes which happen at liquid/gas/solid interface. The surface functionalization with superhydrophobicity or superhydrophilicity affects the underwater wetting state of the electrode, which is an important factor determining the character of the liquid/gas/solid interface and further influencing the performance of catalytic reaction [24–26]. In this context, some recent progresses of the surface/interface engineering of high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for HER, OER and ORR are highlighted. As shown in Fig. 1 , the currently available surface/interface engineering strategies for non-noble metal electrocatalysis are summarized. Specifically, the influence of the interface engineering and surface functionalization on the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts is profoundly discussed. In spite of several reviews involving the surface/interface engineering of materials for energy-related applications [27–30], a comprehensive review of noble metal-free electrocatalyst for OER, ORR and HER is still scarce. It is expected that this review would pave the way for the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts, eventually substituting the noble metal-based materials and bringing the practical utilization of the renewable and clean energy conversion and storage devices into a reality. 2 Electrocatalytic reaction mechanism The reaction pathways for ORR are shown in Fig. 2 (a, b). ORR is a complex reaction that involves several elementary steps with multi-step electron transfer coupled or decoupled with proton transfer. A direct 4e- pathway for ORR is preferred for the achievement of highly efficient fuel cell performance. The pathway involves the formation of OOH*, following by the formation of O* and OH* [31,32]. The adsorption of the intermediates such as O*, OH* and OOH* is critical to ORR kinetics. While, the process of OER is just reverse to that of ORR (Fig. 2a, b). The overall OER involves the adsorption and dissociation of H2O along with the electron and proton-transfer processes [33]. As to HER (Fig. 2c, d), no matter in the acidic or alkaline electrolyte, the first step is adsorption of H on the electrode surface by transferring a proton and an electron (Volmer reaction). In alkaline electrolyte, this reaction requires an additional step of water dissociation, which can introduce an additional energy barrier and further affect the HER reaction rate. The second step contains two possibilities, namely, Heyrovsky reaction and Tafel reaction. For the Heyrovsky reaction, the adsorbed H atom combines with a proton and an electron to form one H2 molecule. For the Tafel reaction, two adjacent adsorbed H atoms combine to form one H2 molecule. The possible rate-controlling step can be determined by the value of Tafel slope [34]. 3 Defect engineering Defects, which can tailor the surface and electronic properties of materials, have been reported to play a positive role in electrochemical reactions. Many different types of defects exist in materials such as heteroatom-doping, vacancies and edge sites. The defects can induce charge redistribution, improve conductivity and optimize adsorption energy of materials, thus affecting the electrocatalytic activity. In principal, defects include 0D point defects (doping and vacancy), 1D line defects (edge and screw dislocation), 2D planar defects and 3D volume defects [35]. This section will discuss the engineering strategies of different types of defects. 3.1 Heteroatom-doping Heteroatom-doping is a most popular and extensively studied method in energy-related applications. The electronic structure of materials can be facilely regulated by doping a small amount of heteroatoms. Metal and non-metal elements such as N, P, S, B, Co, Fe, and Al have been proved as efficient dopants [36]. Thus far, doping heteroatom directly into the matrix, or dual doping is mainly through three main approaches, the first through post-treatment with various chemical reagents and gases (e.g. ammonia, nitric acid and urea), the second approach through in-situ doping during the synthesis of materials with heteroatom-containing precursors (e. g. heterocyclic molecules and melamine) [37]. The third approach is through the pyrolysis of metal organic framework (MOF) or biomass. The latter two kinds of approaches can simultaneously achieve the material synthesis and heteroatom doping, which will be discussed in detail. The post-treatment strategy is not described here, and the reader is thus referred to early reviews on the subject [38]. 3.1.1 In-situ doping of heteroatoms In-situ doping is the dominant approach because it can incorporate heteroatoms homogeneously into the backbone of materials. For the heteroatom-doped carbon materials, the electrocatalytic activity is ascribed to the changes in spin and charge densities of carbon atoms adjacent to the doped heteroatoms due to the electronegativity difference between heteroatoms and carbon atoms [39]. The type of the doping heteroatom, the doping amount and the doping location can greatly affect the catalytic performance. Polypyrrole was used as efficient nitrogen precursor that can achieve maximized pyridinic and graphitic N [40], while both the pyridinic and graphitic N play an important role in the electrocatalytic performance. Through the use of polypyrrole as precursor and the control in pyrolysis temperature, the obtained pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen-enriched carbon paper can act as highly active catalyst for Zn-air batteries. P-doped porous carbons were also synthesized using organophosphonic acid as the P source [41]. The incorporation of P can improve the porous structure properties of carbons and generate abundant and accessible active sites. A suitable doping amount of P is needed for the improvement of catalytic activity towards ORR. A simple and universal heteroatom-doping strategy was developed by conjunction of suitable organic acid and amine species [42,43]. It was proven to be effective in preparing heteroatoms-doped carbons with unique pore structure. Furthermore, the pore structure can be tuned by the introduction of template. The N and S co-doped mesoporous hollow carbon microspheres are synthesized using SBA-15 silicas as the hard template, polydopamine and sodium 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate as N and S sources, respectively [44]. The existence of acid-base interaction between the amine functional groups in dopamine and organosulfonic linkages in sodium 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate allows the facile incorporation of N and S elements in the resultant carbons, exhibiting high-efficiency electrocatalytic activity and good long-term durability compared with commercial Pt/C. Besides, the thermal-decomposition properties (>710 °C) of g-C3N4 allow its use as the self-sacrificing template for the fabrication of porous carbons with sufficient N dopants [45,46]. The uniformly dispersed N-coordinated metal species in carbon nanosheets were synthesized by using graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as the N and C precursors (Fig. 3 a). The resultant materials possess a large percentage of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N, which benefit the oxygen adsorption and reduction and endow them with superior conductivity (Fig. 3b). By using the catalyst as an air cathode, the rechargeable Zn-air batteries present a low charge–discharge potential gap and remarkable cycling stability (Fig. 3c). 3.1.2 Pyrolysis of MOFs The emerging of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has brought a paradigm shift in the design of novel functional porous materials. MOFs represent one of the most prominent families of materials that are commonly used in gas storage, catalysis and separation [47,48]. Apart from their large specific surface area and porosity, MOFs also provide superb structural tunability due to the well-organized metal clusters and organic linkers in the framework, thus facilitating the fabrication of metal (oxide)/carbon or metal (oxide)-N/carbon structure and their composites through pyrolysis [49,50]. The feasibility of applying N-rich MOFs (e.g., ZIF-67, ZIF-8) as both precursors and templates to synthesize high-surface-area N-doped carbon-based electrocatalysts has been reported [51–54]. Other MOFs, such as MIL-101-NH2 (an Al-based MOF), were also selected as a host for the encapsulation of cobalt chloride and thiourea to obtain N and S co-doped porous carbons with Co9S8 nanoparticles immobilized inside [55]. The resulting material exhibits honeycomb-like porous structure with large surface area of 1791 m2 g−1. The remarkable ORR activity and long-term stability and methanol tolerance can be achieved under alkaline conditions. Although MOF-derived materials have made great achievements, the conventional MOF-templating method countered new challenges. Owing to the intrinsic characteristics, the obtained materials by direct carbonization usually have a micropore-dominant structure, which greatly hinders the mass transportation and exposure of active sites during the catalytic process. Moreover, the structure and morphology cannot be easily controlled. The microstructure is easy to collapse and metal atoms tend to agglomerate during the carbonization process. Very recently, some new strategies such as SiO2-coating, SiO2-templating, resorcinol-formaldehyde coating, polydopamine-induced, electrostatic spinning, surfactant-assisted, KOH-assisted, NaCl-assisted and chemical etching have been further developed [56–59]. 3.1.3 Pyrolysis of biomass It has been proven that the nitrogen-containing biomass, such as some biopolymers and carbohydrates, can be used as the feedstock material for N-doped carbon materials [60–62]; This is a promising approach for electrocatalysts from the eco-friendly and renewable resources. The heteroatom-doped porous carbon materials can be obtained from abundant, cost-effective and renewable sources through conversion of biomass [63,64]. Whatever plant or animal biomass, or microorganisms, inherently contains multiple heteroatoms with self-templating structures, facilitating the construction of heteroatoms-doped porous carbons with high yield after carbonization. Indeed, numerous heteroatom-doped carbon materials have been explored from various biomass, such as cocoon silk, human hair, ovalbumin, collagen, peanut shell, eggplant, pine needle, soybean dreg, coffee waste, banana peel [65–68], usually through thermos-chemical process followed some pre- or post-treatment steps, including pyrolysis, gasification, hydrothermal carbonization, combustion and hydrothermal liquefaction [69]. To obtain hierarchically porous carbons from biomass, the extensively used approaches are activation and template method. The activation agents include KOH, phosphoric acid, sodium hydroxide, zinc chloride, sodium thiosulfate, and [ZnCO3]2⋅[Zn(OH)2]3 [70–73], though their use often brings about serious environmental and economic problems and results in micropore-dominated carbons. Despite the great progress has been made in the fabrication of doped carbon materials from biomass, the giant challenges still exist due to its complex composition and structure. Other compounds and elements are included in the biomass, which may improve or lower the catalytic activity and need to be removed in order to clarify the real catalytic active sites. Very recently, thanks to the development of biological extraction technique, a variety of biomass extracts (carbohydrates and amino acids) have been produced as precursors in view of their simple and specific molecular structure, making them more accessible to study the mechanism of catalytic reaction and optimize the catalytic performance of the final materials. Chitosan is an abundant and low-cost biomass derived from chitin. It is the main composition of the shell or exoskeleton of arthropods and it has strong coordination with metal ions [74]. Chitosan-derived cobalt/nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes were synthesized and used as promising ORR electrocatalysts [75]. N and P dual-doped carbon derived from chitosan was also prepared by direct carbonization of chitosan to give carbon and further activation by phosphoric acid during thermal treatment [76]. The optimal catalyst possessed high surface area of 982 m2 g−1, being an excellent cathode catalyst in microbial fuel cell with the maximum power density of 1603.6 ± 80 mW m−2. Moreover, chitosan derivative N-doped hydrothermal carbons can be coated on multiwall carbon nanotubes to enhance their electrocatalytic performance towards ORR [77]. Hydrothermal carbonization of chitosan led to an N-doped hydrothermal carbon shell (NC) adhered to the carbon nanotubes. The following high-temperature treatment under inert atmosphere promoted the formation of N-active sites. The addition of NC layer introduced mesopores of diameter smaller than 4 nm, thus improving the mass transfer and facilitating the catalytic activity. Heteroatom-doping has been considered as an efficient way to modify the surface and electronic properties of materials [78]. The effect of doping is controllable via changing the species, location and amount of the dopants. Moreover, the reaction activity can be enhanced by doping two or three elements with distinct electronegativities. Heteroatom-doping is a simple yet effective strategy in terms of both fabrication process and electronic structure engineering. However, the heteroatom-doping can only provide limited active sites. Accordingly, integrating carbon materials with other active catalysts to construct composites can allow novel physicochemical properties, thus improving the electroactivity further. 3.2 Vacancy The introduction of vacancy has been considered as a valuable strategy to promote the electrocatalytic performance. The theoretical and experimental results reveal that vacancies can lower the energy barriers and be favorable for the adsorption/desorption of water molecules or intermediate reaction species, yielding the optimization of reaction kinetics. Vacancies can also promote the exposure of active sites or act as active sites to increase the density of active sites. Besides, new gap states can be formed within bandgap or bandgap of catalysts can be narrowed by the introduction of vacancies, thus the electrical conductivity of catalysts can be improved [29]. Accordingly, rational design of vacancies in materials can obtain the enhancement of electrocatalyic performance. For transition metal oxides, the incorporation of oxygen vacancies could remarkably increase the reactivity of active sites, showing great enhancement of OER performance [9,79]. The commonly used method of introducing O vacancies is reduction under high-temperature annealing. As shown in Fig. 4 , single-crystal CoO nanorods (SC CoO NRs) with textured pyramidal nanofacets immobilized on carbon fiber paper were synthesized by a cation exchange method in Ar gas at high temperature [80]. CoO NRs were uniformly covered on the entire surface of CFP. The concentration of O vacancies was largely affected by the cation exchange temperature. By creating O vacancies on pyramidal nanofacets the atomic structure of 1D SC CoO NRs could be tuned. DFT calculations revealed that some new electronic states were created when O-vacancy is created in CoO, which are directly responsible for the adsorption of intermediates on the O-vacancies and for high electronic conductivity of CoO, resulting in excellent catalytic performance and durability towards ORR and OER. However, high-temperature annealing is often accompanied by severe aggregation and morphological deformation, leading to the inferior surface area. To this end, some novel strategies were developed, such as wet chemical synthesis strategy [81,82] and plasma-engraved strategy [83]. For instance, a plasma-engraving strategy was applied to design Co3O4 nanosheet catalyst with high surface area (Fig. 5 ). [83] The ratio of Co2+/Co3+ has significant importance on the electronic and catalytic properties of Co3O4. More Co2+ was formed with the generated O vacancies on surface. Besides, the Ar-plasma treatment can engrave the structure to expose more surface sites and the specific surface area is larger than that of pristine Co3O4. It is indicated the specific activity of the plasma-engraved Co3O4 nanosheets is 10 times higher than that of pristine Co3O4. Furthermore, partial oxygen substitution of metal oxides with chalcogen was reported, and the obtained catalyst consisted of O-vacancy-rich and S-deficient cobalt oxysulfide single crystals and N-doped graphene nanomeshes, manifesting significant catalytic activity and stability for OER and ORR [84]. When applied in quasi-solid-state zinc-air batteries, the catalyst assembly can achieve reduced charge and discharge overpotentials and remarkable long cycling stability over 300 cycles at 20 mA cm−2. The introduction of metal cation vacancies can bring surprising characters due to its multifarious electron and orbit distribution. Previous reports have proved their positive role in promoting the electrocatalytic properties of metal compounds. Iron cation vacancies were created in δ-FeOOH nanosheets, which can induce superb water splitting bifunctionality in alkaline media [85]. The structural characterizations and theoretical simulation show that the presence of Fe vacancies can induce an optimal electronic structure and activate the second neighboring Fe to Fe vacancies as the newly formed active sites to enhance water splitting activities and lead to an increased electrical conductivity. In addition, Sn vacancies on the surface of SnCoFe perovskite hydroxide could be preferentially produced instead of Co or Fe vacancies by Ar plasma [86]. The prior formation of Sn vacancies is due to the lower lattice energy and the weak chemical bond of Sn(OH)4. It is indicated that Sn vacancies can promote exposure of active CoFe sites and modulate conductivity and mass transfer, thus greatly improving the OER activity. Of note, the exploration of metal cation vacancies-rich electrocatalysts is limited compared with numerous studies about anion vacancy-rich electrocatalysts due to the high formation energy of metal cation vacancies. On this regard, more efforts should be invested in this area to broaden the research of vacancy-rich electrocatalysts. Besides the usually produced single-type vacancy-rich (cation- or anion-rich) catalysts, the coexistence of two types of vacancies can synergistically accelerate the electrocatalytic process [87]. It is reported that bulk CoFe LDHs can be dry exfoliated into monolayer LDH nanosheets with multiple vacancies including O, Co and Fe vacancies [88,89]. The vacancies can tune the surface electronic structure, decrease the coordination numbers and increase the disorder in the ultrathin nanosheets. The synthesized materials show good OER activity with a low overpotential of 266 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Perovskite-type oxides with a formula of ABO3 are regarded as potential ORR or OER electrocatalysts due to high structural stability and catalytic activity. Partial and complete substitution of earth abundant alkaline earth metals in the A-site and transition metals in the B-site result in different physical properties and electrocatalytic properties [90]. The A-site deficient perovskite Sr0.95Nb0.1Co0.9O3-δ with 52 at% Sr deficiency in SrNb0.1Co0.9O3-δ was synthesized [91], exhibiting a layer structure and offering high activity and stability for low-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells. Taken together, vacancy creation can be tailored and optimized by choosing an appropriate precursor material and the highly efficient type(s) and concentration of vacancies. Besides, selecting a suitable vacancy generation method is important in affecting the physicochemical properties of materials. Till up to now, the type of vacancies is mostly anion vacancies, especially oxygen vacancies. The design and application of other types such as metal cation vacancies, novel anion (C, N and P, etc.) vacancies and multivacancies are still limited. In-depth studies of vacancies at the atomic level is in pressing need. 3.3 Edge sites The introduction of edge sites has also been certified advantageous to ORR, OER and HER. Noticeably, it is indicated that plasma etched graphene without heteroatom-doping exhibits superb ORR activity to N-doped graphene, which can be ascribed to the edge-rich structure [92]. A graphitic carbon catalyst, which is rich in oxygenated carbon edge sites, could catalyze H2O2 generation with a circa 28 times higher mass activity than that of a basal plane-rich CNT [93]. Hence, the edge sites may play a critical role in the electrocatalysis. According to the theoretical calculation, the doping of heteroatoms are energetically tend to substitute carbon atoms at the edge. Both edge-abundant and heteroatom-doping defects have been regarded to redistribute the local electron density and provide a stronger affinity to the intermediates. For the nanocarbon materials, it was demonstrated that a higher edge exposure can offer appropriate locations for heteroatom incorporation [11]. N-doped graphene was explored as efficient electrocatalyst for OER and ORR [94]. The nitrogen substitution of carbon at edge site leads to the superior performance in terms of overpotentials. The ORR active sites on the armchair nanoribbons were identified on the edge carbon near the N atom, while the OER active sites are at the carbon atoms near the N atom. To gain insight into the exact active site of the carbon materials, the rational design of novel functional carbon materials was achieved. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), N-doped and edge-rich graphene mesh (NGM) was synthesized by carbonization of sticky rice as carbon precursor, melamine as nitrogen source and Mg(OH)2 as template [95]. The morphology is ultrathin graphene flakes, which are mainly few-layer type with nanosized holes all over the plane (Fig. 6b). The possible active sites derived from the N-doping, topological defects and edge sites are proposed in Fig. 6(c). Interestingly, the N-doped moieties present a higher overpotential compared to the pristine graphene nanoribbon apart from the PR configuration for the ORR. The sites near the edge possess a lower overpotential among all sites induced by N-doping, demonstrating the positive effect of edge sites. However, the accurate function of edge site in carbocatalysis is still limited. It is indispensable to fabricate a carbocatalyst with tailorable edge contents and exclude other influencing factors on ORR as well. It has been reported the successfully implemented edge engineering to carbons with tailorable edging degree. The outer walls of MWCNTs were unzipped by oxidative process with oxidation ratio (the mass ratio of KMnO4 to MWCNTs) from 1 to 6 to expose various content of edges lengthwise [96], and the decreased I 2D/I G and upshifted G band indicate the decreasing intact inner tubes in the samples after the unzipping process. A proper edging degree (the oxidation ratio is 3) can facilitate the ORR process, confirming the intrinsic catalytic activity of edge sites. Besides, the edge sites can anchor and accommodate heteroatoms into carbons. The final superior electrocatalytic activity towards the ORR is attributed to the synergistic effect between active edge sites and edge site-favored doping. For the transition metal sulphide-based electrocatalysts, designing nanostructures with more edge sites is proved to be one of the most effective strategies compared to the bulk counterparts because abundant defects lead to the cracking of crystal and thus increase the accessible internal surface area [97–100]. As seen in Fig. 7 (a), the defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets with controllable defect and morphology modulations can be achieved by adjusting the concentration of precursors with excess thiourea [101]. Many dislocations and distortions can be observed, suggesting a defect-rich structure (Fig. 7b). In the reconstructed models of the defect-rich structure, additional active edge sites arising from defects could be revealed. The generation of defects led to partial cracking of the catalytically inert basal planes, thus exposing additional active edge sites. The resultant defect-rich MoS2 present a smaller onset overpotential of 120 mV for HER compared to the highly crystalline samples (Fig. 7c). In addition, chemical etching is also usually used as an effective top-down method to engineer the surface structures of materials through formation of nanoscale pores and edges. A high density of active edge sites on MoS2 basal plane could be created by a facile steam etching method [102]. By controlling the etching temperature, different edge morphologies including 1D nano-channel, 2D in-plane triangular pit and 3D out-of-plane cavity surface structures were created. The generated active edge sites could decrease its surface free energy barrier and improve its catalytic activity towards the HER. Notably, for the supported MoS2, the choice of support is of great significance in determining the HER activity. The catalytic activity at the Mo-edge can be optimally tailored by the choice of support [103]. Similar to the MoS2-type materials, the chalcogenide atoms at the edges of CoX2 catalysts are active sites for HER. Introducing Ni dopant into CoSe2 to achieve Ni0.33Co0.67Se2 with increased number of active edge sites has been reported by in situ selenization process of (Ni,Co)(CO3)0.5(OH)0.11H2O precursor [104]. By introduction of heterogeneous spin states (Ni into CoSe2), a disordered atomic arrangement in Ni0.33Co0.67Se2 nanosheets was realized. The obtained catalysts offer a promising HER activity and stability in both strongly acidic and basic media. Apart from the transition metal chalcogenides, transition metal oxides have also been engineered by edge defects. Surface edge sites can act as a critical factor for enhancing the catalytic performance. Core–shell Mn3O4@Co x Mn3− x O4 nanoparticles were obtained via a seed-mediated growth method [105]. There exist abundant edge sites with unsaturated coordination on the shells of Mn3O4@Co x Mn3− x O4 nanoparticles. The edge sites with unsaturated coordination present intense affinity for OH− in the alkaline media, which can promote the OER performance. The as-obtained materials exhibit enhanced OER properties with an overpotential of 246 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1. It is indicated that the exposed edges are more active than the basal plane. Edge-abundant defects in materials have been regarded to redistribute the local electron density and provide a stronger affinity to the intermediates. Edge site has also been reported to have a critical effect on the heteroatom-doping process in electrocatalysis. The engineering of edge sites in materials such as nanocarbons, transition metal sulphides and oxides have been achieved. Controllable design of defects, regarding their composition and location, is highly desirable for studying the relationship between defects and electrocatalytic performance, providing scientific guidance concerning how to optimize the catalytic performance. 4 Heterostructure design The design of heterostructures have been achieved much attention in the field of energy conversion and storage. The strategies of heterostructure design include the design of core–shell heterostructure, the utilization of support effect and the construction of single-atom catalyst. Compared with the materials possess single structure, the heterostructure materials have demonstrated great electrochemical performance due to the synergistic effect on the interfaces among the multiple components [106]. The presence of interfaces can result in the optimization of electronic configuration through the interfacial electron transfer in the heterostructures [107]. Various heterostructures have been explored to act as efficient electrocatalysts, such as NiO/Ni(OH)2, MoS2/CoS2, CoS x /Ni3S2, MoS2/Fe3O4, MoS2/CuS, NiO/Ni, MoS2/graphene [108–114]. The interface engineering through constructing heterostructures has been confirmed to be an effective approach for developing high-efficiency electrocatalysts. MoS2/Ni3S2 heterostructures with abundant interfaces were synthesized using a nickel foam and (NH4)2MoS4 through a solvothermal reaction in N,N-dimethylformamide [115]. The outer MoS2 nanosheets are decorated on the surface of the inner Ni3S2 nanoparticles, thus generating abundant interfaces. The resultant heterostructures show excellent electrocatalytic activities for both OER and HER in alkaline media. 4.1 Core-shell heterostructure In fact, the heterostructures constructed in a core–shell form have been attracted much attention. Co9S8@MoS2/carbon nanofibers hybrids were obtained via S vapor assisted graphitization of polyacrylonitrile nanofibers containing Co(NO3)2 and (NH4)2MoS4 [116]. There exist interactions between MoS2 and Co9S8 phases due to the direct contact of them caused by the core–shell structures. The resultant materials indicate superb performance towards HER and OER due to the electrocatalytic synergistic effect of the nanointerfaces generated by the contacting regions between MoS2 shell and Co9S8 core. The nanointerfaces obtained by electrostatic spinning can strengthen electron transfer between Mo and Co through the intermediate S atoms bonded to both metals, further achieving the enhanced catalytic activity. Likewise, Co9S8@MoS2 core–shell heterostructures were also prepared by a solvothermal approach and a following annealing treatment, which can act as trifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting and Zn-air batteries [117]. It is revealed that the introduction of nanointerface can deeply influence its charge state to boost the catalytic activity. Besides, the core–shell structure can promote the synergistic effect between two phases and provide abundant catalytically active sites. The core–shell heterostructures possess different anions have also been reported, such as MoS2@MoP, MoO3@MoS2 and Ni(OH)2@CuS [118–120]. The core–shell heterojunctions offer an efficient way to promote the catalytic performance based on the synergistic action of the shell and core components. In a MoS2@MoP configuration, the synergy of S and P can give enhanced performance for HER and the shell MoP shows better activity and stability than MoS2, which can protect the catalyst from degradation in the application [118]. Combining the MoS2 shell (high catalytic activity and stability in acids) and MoO3 core (high conductivity and high aspect ratio foundation), the resultant MoO3@MoS2 exhibits superior activity for HER in strong acids [119]. Similarly, the inner Ni(OH)2 mesoporous shell can create abundant active sites on the surface and the CuS out layer can improve electron transportation in the Ni(OH)2@CuS configuration [120]. The heterostructure materials have aroused much interest due to the synergistic effect on the interfaces among the multiple components. Researchers have invested in developing a number of strategies to engineer a hetero-interface to employ the synergistic effects [121]. The mutual interaction between multiple components is of great importance. Core-shell structure can increase the contact region of interface and promote the synergistic effect between two phases. How to utilize the best properties of each component while mitigating their deficiencies is a great challenge. 4.2 Support effect The heterostructures integrating active species with conductive carbon or metallic support is among the most investigated strategy. The use of conductive carbon support can not only improve the conductivity of the catalyst, but also promote the dispersion of the active species to provide more active sites. Carbon nanotubes decorated with CoP nanocrystals were prepared via a low-temperature phosphidation process [122], exhibiting superior catalytic activity towards the HER in acidic media, which is ascribed to high electronic conductivity of CNT (facilitates charge transfer) and the small size of CoP nanocrystals (favors the exposure of more active sites). Our group prepared N-doped cobalt phosphate/carbon nanotube hybrids by hydrothermal treatment of N-containing cobalt phosphonate and oxidized carbon nanotube followed by high-temperature calcination [123]. The phosphonate-derived materials exhibit a graphitic carbon layer around Co nanoparticles, endowing them with good conductivity and stability. And the synergistic interface interaction between cobalt phosphate and CNT contributes to the enhancement of ORR catalytic activity in alkaline media. Heteroatom-doped carbon has also been utilized as the catalyst support [124–126]. Among them, metal/nitrogen/carbon (M–N x –C, M = Co, Ni, Fe), in which the active sites involve surface nitrogen coordinated with metals [127], are proved to show great activity towards ORR. Iron carbide nanoparticles encapsulated in mesoporous Fe-N-doped carbon nanofibers were synthesized [128], possessing multiple effective intrinsic active sites and high surface area with a mesoporous structure, which exhibited excellent ORR activity in both alkaline and acidic media. Very recently, 2D nanosheets materials have been a great interest owing to their high surface area. The presence of more exposed surface-facet atoms in these 2D materials allow them to be an ideal platform for engineering physicochemical properties via surface modifications [129]. In order to design the highly efficient and multifunctional electrocatalysts, the hybrids named “van der Waals heterostructures”, such as graphene and other 2D nanolayers, have been attracted much attention. These heterostructures can gain full potential of the multiple 2D complementing counterparts. A heterostructured Ni-Fe layered double hydroxide nanosheet@defective graphene hybrids were synthesized via electrostatic flocculation [130]. The defective graphene possesses highly active defective sites and high conductivity and can provide efficient anchor sites to directly couple transition metal atoms (Ni and Fe) on 2D NiFe LDH layers. Combining these two 2D materials to construct heterostructured hybrids can optimize direct interfacial contact between transition metal atoms and defects on carbon, enhancing electron transfer and shortening diffusion distance. Thus, the hybrids exhibit advanced electrocatalytic activity and stability for both OER and HER in an alkaline solution. A 3D mesoporous van der Waals heterostructure of N-doped MoS2 and graphene via a CVD method was also constructed [131]. The morphology, edge, defect, interface and electronic structure of the materials can all be engineered, and the materials show excellent electrocatalytic performance towards HER, OER and ORR. To improve the conductivity and stability of heterostructures, self-supported electrocatalysts have been a growing trend. They can be deployed as working electrodes without use of any polymer binder by directly growing the active species on substrates or by forming free-standing films or monoliths [132]. The substrates usually include nickel foam, Cu foil, carbon fiber paper, and carbon cloth, etc. [133–137]. Several strategies such as electrodeposition, chemical bath deposition and hydrothermal treatment have been used to construct the self-supported heterostructures. As indicated in Fig. 8 (a), Co3O4-carbon porous nanowire arrays were prepared by carbonization of MOF directly grown on Cu foil under N2 atmosphere [134]. The obtained nanowires exhibit a smooth surface, indicating that Co3O4 and carbon are well integrated inside them (Fig. 8b). The synergistic effect between porous nanowire array configuration and MOF-derived in situ carbon incorporation contributes to the improvement of surface area, stability and mass/charge transport, further enhancing the catalytic activity and durability towards OER and ORR. Similarly, P-doped g-C3N4 directly grown on CFP was designed through acid-base interaction between melamine and ethylene diphosphonic acid [135]. The resultant 3D foldable and rollable electrode presents superior catalytic activity towards OER and ORR. Additionally, the introduction of substrates often increases the cost and weight of an electrode, which will limit their application in practical devices. Thus, forming free-standing films or monoliths without using substrates has also aroused increasing interest. Our group fabricated the N,P-codoped 3D reduced graphene oxide aerogel (NPGA) supported Co2P2O7 particles (CoPi/NPGA) via the self-polymerization of organophosphonic acid and cobalt salts on GO under hydrothermal treatment and high-temperature pyrolysis [138] (Fig. 9 a). The presence of 3D interconnected and porous network facilitate the exposure of active sites and the mass transportation (Fig. 9b). Taking advantage of the synergistic effect between CoPi particles and porous reduced GO aerogel, the obtained materials exhibit high activity towards ORR and OER (Fig. 9c), showing great potential in the field of Zn-air battery with the open circuit potential of 1.41 V and a peak power density of 138 mW cm−2 in the Zn-air battery test (Fig. 9d). Integrating active species on conductive support to construct heterostructures can improve the conductivity and promote the dispersion of the active species to provide more active sites. The interaction between active species and supports can greatly affect the activity and durability of a catalyst [139]. Self-supported heterostructure catalysts have been attracted much attention. Choosing a suitable support is critical to support-assisted catalysts. Fabricating support-free heterostructures may lead to simplified fabrication processes and enhancement of mass transport and durability. 4.3 Single-atom catalysis Single-atom catalysis has become the most active research frontier in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [140]. Owing to the maximum atom utilization efficiency and the unique geometric and electronic properties and the cationic (or sometimes anionic) nature of the isolated catalytic sites, single-atom catalyst (SAC) can achieve the highest catalytic activity and superior selectivity in catalysis. It is also indicated that SACs may exhibit superb stability compared to their nanoparticle counterparts due to the strong covalent and ionic bonding between single metal sites and the support [140]. However, single atoms are preferable to migrate and agglomerate during the electrocatalytic process, thus how to stabilize and prepare the high-density SACs remains to be a big challenge. Several strategies have been explored to fabricate SACs, including atomic layer deposition, wet-impregnation and coprecipitation [141–143]. Considering that the high-temperature pyrolysis may lead to the aggregation of metal atoms and break the N-containing functional group, choosing a suitable support is of immense significance. The mutual metal-support interaction plays an important role in stabilizing the isolated atom over supports. Among the non-noble metal atoms, single Co, Fe or Ni atom has been reported to be dispersed on various carbon matrix with a common MN4C4 moiety such as hierarchically porous carbon and heteroatom-doped carbon [144–146]. MOFs such as ZIF-8 and MOF-545 were used as precursors to produce SACs due to their high N content, structural tenability and pore confinement effect [147,148]. Biomass-derived carbons with numerous functional groups have also applied as good support materials because they can provide high surface area and further facilitate the dispersion of metal atoms [65]. In addition to the single Fe or Co atoms, single-atom Fe-N4 catalytic sites anchored on N-doped carbon were obtained deriving from bimetallic Zn/Fe polyphthalocyanine [149]. Benefiting from the synergistic effect between atomically dispersed Fe-N4 and porous carbon, the resultant materials can act as superior catalyst for water splitting and Zn-air batteries. Notably, using ZIF-8 as precursor, atomically dispersed dual-metal Fe and Mn anchored on N-doped carbons were fabricated, demonstrating high catalytic activity towards ORR [150]. Single-atom catalyst has emerged as a novel highly efficient electrocatalyst due to its superior activity, selectivity and stability compared to its nanoparticle counterparts. Various types of SACs such as Co, Fe, Ni and Fe-N4 anchored on carbons have been explored. However, there is still a long way to go due to some unsolved problems such as how to increase the active site density of single atom and achieve the large-scale preparation. 5 Surface functionalization Surface functionalization signifies the chemical modification by grafting specific molecules or groups onto the surface of materials [151]. Hence, surface functionalization is a post-processing method, which can attach various molecules onto the surface of materials to easily modify their physical or chemical properties. It has been proposed as a promising complement or substitute for offering materials with catalytic properties. 5.1 Covalent interaction Covalent interaction between material and molecules means the interaction is along with covalent bond form. For the carbon materials, surface functionalization can covalently attach some groups such as hydroxyls, epoxy and carboxylic acids on their surface. A biomimetic axial imidazole coordinated iron porphyrin ((DFTPP)Fe-Im was anchored onto the surface of multiwalled carbon nanotubes through imidazole functionalization of carbon nanotubes [152]. The functionalized MWCNTs present high ORR activity, stability and methanol tolerance in both alkaline and acidic media compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst. Besides, nitrobenzene could covalently bonding to MWCNT and graphene via C–C bonding. The strong electron-accepting ability can withdraw electrons from carbon atoms in MWCNTs and graphene sheets, resulting in their modified electronic properties and electrocatalytic activity [153,154]. Notably, the covalent functionalization also allows the controlled introduction of heteroatoms in nanocarbon materials. Through the covalent functionalization of small organic molecules and the following thermal treatment, heteroatom-doped graphene nanosheets can be prepared [155]. The type of precursors used determine the degrees and configurations of heteroatoms within carbon framework. The prepared graphene nanosheets exhibited good electrocatalytic activity and durability towards ORR in alkaline media. 5.2 Non-covalent interaction Non-covalent interactions between the molecules and materials include electrostatic interaction, van der waals force, coordination bonds, hydrogen bond and π-π stacking interactions. 5.2.1 Design of superaerophobic and superaerophilic surfaces For gas-involving reactions, including gas-evolution reactions (GERs) and gas-consumption reactions (GCRs), the controllable of underwater wetting state of electrode is of great significance due to the reaction happens on the liquid/gas/solid triphase interface. During large-scale catalytic GERs, such as OER and HER, excessive amounts of H2 and O2 bubbles are rapidly generated at high current density. There exists the aggregation of these gas bubbles on the contact surface between electrolyte and electrocatalysts. How to accelerate gas release from the surface is critical, because the attached gas bubbles would hinder electron transport and electrolyte diffusion, reduce the active area of catalyst, and thereby leading to degradation of catalytic activity and stability. It is indicated that the design of superaerophobic and superhydrophilic surface structures could solve this problem [156,157]. On the other side, for GCRs, such as ORR, the design of superaerophilic and superhydrophobic surface structures can accelerate the gas-diffusion process and electron transport, thus promoting the catalytic performance. In principal, a superaerophobic surface means a surface with high bubble contact angle (usually >150°) underwater and a low adhesion force, while a superaerophilic surface is defined as low bubble contact angle (<10°) and a high adhesion force. Similarly, the superhydrophobic surface is a surface with high liquid contact angle (usually >150°) and a low adhesion force, while a superhydrophilic surface shows a low liquid contact angle (<10°) and a high adhesion force [156–158]. Until now, several groups have reported the design of superaerophobic/superhydrophilic and superaerophilic/superhydrophobic surfaces for electrochemical reactions. The fabrication of micro-nanostructured materials on conductive substrates to form integrated electrode is considered as an efficient strategy because the micro-/nanostructured surface can induce tailorable adhesion behavior of gas bubbles and the direct interaction between catalyst and substrate would offer a superior electron transport [159,160]. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), CoS2 film, microwires and nanowires were generated on graphite disk or glass substrate [161]. Compared with film and microwires, nanowires are superior in facilitating bubbles detached from the electrode surface (Fig. 10b), which can hinder the H2 bubbles from gathering and degrading the catalyst. As a result, the nanowires show great catalytic activity towards HER. It is ascribed to the micro- and nanostructures which can increase the effective electrode surface area and lead to the facile release of H2 bubbles from the surface, further improving the catalytic activity and mechanical stability of the catalyst. The synthesis strategies of superhydrophilic electrode surface for GERs have been reported such as electrodeposition, air-plasma and electroless deposition [162–164]. The substrates vary from powdery materials (e.g. graphdiyne) to 3D self-supported materials (e.g. nickel foam and carbon cloth) [163,165–168]. Besides, the design of superaerophobic surface of electrode was also reported to avoid the aggregation of gas bubbles at large current densities [169]. Very recently, an efficient electrocatalyst possessing both superaerophobic and superhydrophilic surfaces was engineered. As shown in Fig. 10(c), CoMoS x was in-situ supported on nickel foam (CoMoS x /NF) through the chalcogel metathesis reaction [167], exhibiting hierarchical structures which allow them with both superhydrophilic and underwater superaerophobic properties (Fig. 10d) and further facilitate the access of electrolyte and acceleration of mass transfer. The CoMoS x /NF catalysts present impressive catalytic water splitting performances and stability in alkaline electrolyte. For GCRs, such as ORR, the design of micro-nanostructured electrode with superaerophilic/superhydrophobic surface is favorable for promoting the electron transport and gas-diffusion process. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), Co-incorporated N-doped CNT arrays on carbon fiber paper were fabricated [160]. The direct growth of CNT on carbon fiber paper and poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE)-modification rendered a superaerophilic surface. This unique structure shows high ORR activity in both alkaline and acidic media and long-term stability under large current densities. Furthermore, by controllable tuning of the underwater wetting state of the superhydrophobic electrode, the ORR catalytic performance can be highly boosted [169]. It is indicated that the superhydrophobic electrode with particularly underwater Wenzel-Cassie coexistent state is the essence for stabilizing the triphase interface (Fig. 11b). The increase of liquid or gas phase by creating UW-state (underwater Wenzel state) or UC-state (underwater Cassie state) could result in the diminishment of the triphase interface and retardment of ORR proceeding. 5.2.2 Other non-covalent interactions The local charge state of the materials can be varied by introducing the molecule on their surface [170]. Poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA), as a positively charged polyelectrolyte which possesses a strong electron-withdrawing ability, was used to functionalize CNTs and graphene through intermolecular charge-transfer between CNTs or graphene and PDDA. The resultant heteroatom-free PDDA-functionalized CNTs exhibit remarkable catalytic performance for ORR, which is similar to that of commercial Pt/C yet a better long-term durability and fuel selectivity [171]. Similar results were also found in PDDA-functionalized graphene [172]. Furthermore, loading CoMn2O4 on PDDA-CNTs was reported to improve the ORR activity and durability of CoMn2O4 in alkaline and neutral media [173]. Additionally, it was reported that the intermolecular charge-transfer between SWCNTs and adsorbed C60 molecules can lead to superior electrocatalytic performance of C60-SWCNT for ORR, OER and HER in alkaline, acidic and neutral media [174], while, neither pure SWCNTs nor C60 show significant catalytic activity. This indicates that intermolecular charge-transfer induced by the adsorbed C60 contributes to the superior catalytic performance and may provide a facile strategy to develop a metal-free, heteroatom-/defect-free multifunctional electrocatalyst towards ORR, OER and HER. In addition, by introducing some electrochemically inert polymers such as poly(vinyl alcohol) and poly(vinyl acetate) with polar O-containing groups through non-covalent interactions on the surface of CNTs, the OER performance could be greatly boosted [175]. At the polymer@CNT interface, the wrapped CNTs by adsorbed polymers can form a favorable environment for stabilizing OER intermediates via hydrogen bonding to promote OER kinetics. The resultant polymer-wrapped CNT catalysts present high OER performance in alkaline media, which can be ascribed to the synergistic effect between the intrinsic topological defects in CNTs and the co-catalyst function of the wrapped polymer layer. Surface functionalization includes covalent interaction and non-covalent interaction between molecules and catalysts. The controlled introduction of heteroatoms into nanomaterials can be achieved by covalent functionalization. For GCRs, the nanostructured surface with superaerophilic/superhydrophobic property is able to facilitate gas diffusion with electron transport, thus improving the catalytic performance. In analogy, the catalytic performance and stability for GERs can be enhanced greatly by engineering the electrode to a superaerophobic/superhydrophilic structure with fast release of gas bubbles. Designing other non-covalent interactions between polyelectrolyte or organic polymers and materials to obtain polyelectrolyte or organic polymers adsorbed materials can improve the electrocatalytic performance induced by intermolecular charge-transfer. More novel adsorbed molecules can be continually explored to enrich the varieties of surface-functionalized catalysts and lead to further advancement of electrochemical reactions. 6 Summary and outlook The exploration of high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts to accelerate the kinetics of ORR, OER and HER is of critical significance in the renewable and clean energy conversion technologies. An outstanding electrocatalyst must meet a number of requirements, such as abundance, low cost, facile synthesis, high activity and selectivity and superior stability. Researchers investigated a variety of strategies to achieve an ideal catalyst. In this review, we have given an overview of the recent advances in designing the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for ORR, OER and HER through the surface/interface engineering. The great progresses achieved by various strategies in this field offer a new fertile ground for the development of high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts. In spite of the significant achievements mentioned in this review, a series of challenges still exist in this rapid growing field for catalysis. First, the in-depth research into the mechanism of ORR, OER and HER should be carried out for better design of the electrocatalysts. Until now, the exact reaction processes about them and the active sites of electrocatalysts still remain unclear. Hence, combining the advance techniques such as in-situ spectroscopic analysis and electrode dynamics analysis and theoretical calculations to obtain more detailed information about the possible reaction mechanism is an indispensable approach. Second, the defects in catalysts, including heteroatom-doping, vacancies, edge sites and lattice defects, play a crucial role in electrochemical reactions via changing the electronic charge and electron density distributions. Heteroatom-doping is a convenient and efficient approach to enhance the electrocatalytic activity. The rational doping principles and an in-depth understanding of doping mechanism are urgently required for the achievement of high-efficiency electrocatalysts. Moreover, the amount of catalytic active sites induced by heteroatom-doping are still limited, which may prevent its further practical applications. Oxygen vacancies are among the most investigated vacancies. However, other types of defects (metal or non-metal elements) should be further explored for improving the electrocatalytic activity. Besides, new synthetic strategies for defects with controllable type and location should be discussed in order to identify the real active sites of defects. More importantly, novel characterization techniques and DFT calculations to study the relation between various defects and catalytic performance are highly desirable. Third, the design of heterostructures for electrocatalysis has been extensively studied due to the interface synergistic effect between different components. However, multiple-interfacial components with controllable nanoscale assembly are hardly to be achieved. The exploration of synthetic strategies to obtain noble metal-free electrocatalysts with tunable particle size and multiple interfaces is still needed. Integrating the active species and conductive support to construct heterostructures can increase their conductivity and expose more active sites. There is a growing trend to fabricate self-supported electrocatalysts because they can be directly deployed as working electrodes without use of any polymer binder that greatly improve the conductivity and stability of heterostructures. Very recently, single-atom catalyst has been attracted broad attention, yet its development is still in its infancy. The characterization of the active centers in various SACs is hardly to be accomplished. The large-scale preparation of SACs still remains to be a great challenge due to the low yield of conventional methods. Finally, surface functionalization of materials, such as the design of superaerophobic and superaerophilic surfaces, polyelectrolyte and organic molecule functionalization, offer a possibility for promoting the electrocatalytic performance. It provides an efficient, facile and cost-effective strategy to obtain metal-free, heteroatom- and defect-free multifunctional electrocatalysts towards ORR, OER and HER. However, the catalytic performance after surface functionalization is still need improved. More efforts should be put into developing novel surface functionalization approaches to promote the practical applications of electrochemical energy conversion systems. Dai, Energy Environ. Sci. 10 (2017) 2312-2317. Hui Zhao received her PhD degree in Physical Chemistry under the supervision of Prof. Zhong-Yong Yuan from Nankai University in 2017. She is currently working at Liaocheng University as a Lecturer. Her research focuses on the advanced energy materials and electrodes for fuel cells, water splitting and metal-air batteries. Zhong-Yong Yuan received his PhD degree in Physical Chemistry from Nankai University in 1999. He worked as a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 1999 to 2001. He then moved to Belgium, working as a research fellow at the University of Namur from 2001 to 2005, prior to joining Nankai University as a full professor. He is a fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry. His research interests are mainly on the self-assembly of hierarchically nanoporous and nanostructured materials for energy and environmental applications.

coredata.dc:description: To date, much efforts have been devoted to the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for hydrogen- and oxygen-involving energy conversion reactions, due to their abundance, low cost and multifunctionally. Surface/interface engineering is found to be effective in achieving novel physicochemical properties and synergistic effects in nanomaterials for electrocatalysis. Among various engineering strategies, heteroatom-doping has been regarded as a most promising method to improve the electrocatalytic performance via the regulation of electronic structure of catalysts, and numerous works were reported on the synthesis method and mechanism investigation of heteroatom-doping electrocatalysts, though the heteroatom-doping can only provide limited active sites. Engineering of other defects such as vacancies and edge sites and construction of heterostructure have shown to open up a potential avenue for the development of noble metal-free electrocatalysts. In addition, surface functionalization can attach various molecules onto the surface of materials to easily modify their physical or chemical properties, being as a promising complement or substitute for offering materials with catalytic properties. This paper gives the insights into the diverse strategies of surface/interface engineering of the high-efficiency noble metal-free electrocatalysts for energy-related electrochemical reactions. The significant advances are summarized. The unique advantages and mechanisms for specific applications are highlighted. The current challenges and outlook of this growing field are also discussed.
